Award.AwardTitle: Study of Anomalous Magnetism and Superconductivity in Selected Lanthanides, Alkalis and Noble Metals Under Extreme Pressure
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract
Whereas simple materials are easier to understand, complex materials are more interesting and more likely to lead to innovative applications. In this single investigator award extremely high pressures, as high as 2-3 million atmospheres, are applied to very simple and soft materials, like the alkali metals. Such extreme pressures are able to continuously transform these metals into surprisingly complex materials that may become superconducting, ferromagnetic or even insulating. The fact that a single sample can be brought through extreme compression to exhibit such anomalous behavior allows one to gain a deeper understanding of what makes them tick. This enhanced understanding, on the other hand, facilitates the design of materials with useful properties at ambient pressure. In elements called "rare-earths", high pressures have been found to induce magnetic ordering at very high temperatures. With some luck this work could lead to the development of superior permanent magnets, a ubiquitous material in everyday life. The proposed experiments give undergraduate and graduate students the opportunity to learn and develop a multitude of essential experimental techniques; these students also benefit from scientific collaborations with groups both in the US and abroad.

Technical Abstract
The research in this single investigator award has two primary thrust directions. The first is the transformation under extreme compression of canonical simple free-electron metals, such as the alkali metals, into materials with highly anomalous electronic properties. These properties include superconductivity at relatively high temperatures, metal-semiconductor or metal-insulator transitions or even Pauli paramagnetic to itinerant ferromagnetic transitions. This project will study in depth to ultrahigh pressures the superconducting phase diagram and critical magnetic field behavior of selected alkali metals as well as their alloys and compounds. The second thrust direction has evolved out of the discovery by the PI's group of magnetic order at temperatures well above ambient in selected lanthanides under extreme pressures. This raises the possibility of a permanent magnet material superior to the current record holder Nd-Fe-B. Further materials of interest are the hydrides, particularly following the very recent discovery of superconductivity in sulfur dihydride near 190 K. The proposed experiments give undergraduate and graduate students an excellent opportunity to learn and develop important laboratory techniques and collaborate with groups both in the US and abroad.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are 98 different kinds of naturally occurring miniature building blocks called atoms or elements. Combining a selection of these in the right way has led to materials with useful properties in the everyday world like steel for cars and bridges or doped silicon for electronic chips that power our computers. Bringing the right atoms together in the proper way to result in a material with specific desirable properties is extremely difficult and fortuitous due to our lack of basic understanding. The easiest materials to fully understand are the elemental solids that consist of only one type of atom. Exposing such elemental solids to a wide range of temperatures, pressures, and magnetic fields greatly adds to our understanding.

In figure 1 is shown the Periodic Table of all 98 naturally occurring elements from hydrogen (H) to Lawrencium (Lr). Those 31 elemental solids that are naturally superconducting have their boxes colored in yellow. Those 24 that must be squeezed to high pressures, in some cases to millions of atmospheres, to become superconducting have light green boxes, giving a total of 55 elemental superconductors in all. High pressures can create new materials out of old but also further understanding so that one can better know how to make designer materials that are really useful to society.

To make some elements like Rb, Eu or Yb superconducting they must be squeezed to pressures between ?and 1 million atmospheres. Such enormous pressures can now be achieved in the laboratory by pressing two small opposing diamond anvils together in a pressure cell, as shown in figure 2. In this figure the upper anvil is not shown. Both anvils have a flat surface (culet) only 0.5 mm in diameter. The Re gasket is a thin disk with diameter 3 mm that serves to hold the Rb sample in place when the high pressure is applied, thus allowing electrical resistance measurements. Since Rb is very soft, like butter, a cup has to be shaped (see figure 2) to prevent Rb from escaping under pressure. In figure 3 student Yuhang Deng is seen preparing a pressure cell under a powerful stereo microscope. In figure 4 the electrical resistance of Rb metal is plotted as a function of temperature near 2 K (-271oC) at various pressures. When a metal becomes superconducting, its resistance drops suddenly towards zero. The data in figure 4 document student Yuhang Deng's discovery of the latest (24th) known element to become superconducting, namely, the alkali metal rubidium (Rb).

The far-left column of the periodic table in figure 1 contains the alkali metals Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs, and Fr. As elemental solids these alkali metals are the simplest metals known and none are magnetic under normal or high-pressure conditions. In contrast, the 2nd row of elements from the bottom, the lanthanides, are almost all strongly magnetic, each atom possessing a permanent bar magnet. It is thus not surprising that almost all lanthanides show magnetic order, like iron, only much stronger. The most powerful permanent magnet material known contains neodymium (Nd). Students Jinhyuk Lim, Jing Son, and Yuhang Deng have applied pressures near 2 million atmospheres to elemental solids of Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, and Yb and shown that highly anomalous magnetic properties appear as their "permanent" magnets begin to weaken. In fact, Eu and Yb were found to even become superconducting under pressure, the 22nd and 23rd such superconducting elements in the periodic table.

The high-pressure studies in this NSF project have explored the superconducting and magnetic properties of the alkali and lanthanide metals over a wide range of pressure and temperature, making important contributions to our basic understanding of both kinds of phenomena. With this understanding future work will be in a better position to make materials with specified properties of benefit to society.
